msgSnippet: Again, this problem is due to TestCaseClassloader. You re right about the solution. This particular exception is even more puzzling than the oft-encountered

To: "'junit@yahoogroups.com'" <junit@yahoogroups.com>
Subject: RE: [junit] SwingUI and AWTUI don't work with PROJECTX?
Date: Thu, 19 Jul 2001 14:00:26 -0400
MIME-Version: 1.0
X-Mailer: Internet Mail Service (5.5.2650.21)
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
From: Scott Stirling <sstirling@...>

Again, this problem is due to TestCaseClassloader. You're right about the
s=
olution.

This particular exception is even more puzzling than the oft-enco=
untered
LinkageError because you get it even though you probably didn't cha=
nge any
of the classes that supposedly changed, right?  IncompatibleClassCh=
angeError
is a subclass of LinkageError.

The JVM is fooled by the defining=
 loader part of the class's type (every
runtime class type =3D fullyQualifi=
edClassname;definingLoaderInstance) into
"assuming" that com.sun.xml.tree.X=
mlDocument, which would have been loaded
by the JVM's system class loader d=
ue to the default excluded.properties,
does not implement org.w3c.dom.Docum=
ent, which would have been loaded by
JUnit's class loader, also due to the =
default excluded.properties.  Well of
course it does -- at compile time!  B=
ut at runtime the "types" of the two
classes are defined by their name plus=
 their defining classloader's
instance, so the JVM doesn't see them as meet=
ing the required contract.

This is the third significant problem we've see=
n caused by the combination
of XML classes and the default exclusion list i=
n JUnit's custom class
loader: LinkageErrors and this IncompatibleClassChan=
geError revolving around
JAXP and other Sun XML classes that depend on org.=
w3c and org.xml.sax
classes, and ClassCastExceptions with EJB home object s=
tubs.  I've written
explanations for all three of them in the past two week=
s (see recent list
archives if you care).  They all share the same root cau=
se.

For a great explanation of the underlying issues with Java 2 classload=
ers
and loader constraints, see

"Dynamic Class Loading in the Java Virtual=
 Machine"
by Sheng Liang and Gilad Bracha
Presented at OOPSLA'98, October 2=
0-22, Vencouver, Canada. 
http://java.sun.com/people/sl/

Scott Stirling
JR=
un QA
Macromedia

 still it doesn't work.
> 
> I have been trying with different options, and=
 when "Reload 
> classes every
> run"  is unchecked, it works. I've been re=
ading some stuff at 
> Sourceforge,
> and it seems that the problem is some=
thing to do with the
> "junit\runner\excluded.properties" file. I have not =
tested 
> yet, but may be I
> have to exclude org.w3c.* and org.xml.* in or=
der to do it 
> work properly.
> 
> I will let you know about this.
> 
> Di=
ego
>

> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "Jason Rogers" <jason.roge=
rs@...>
> To: <junit@yahoogroups.com>
> Sent: Thursday, July 19,=
 2001 3:26 PM
> Subject: RE: [junit] SwingUI and AWTUI don't work with PROJ=
ECTX?
> 
> 
> This sounds like the problem we were getting with some CORBA =

> applications.
> We needed to bootstrap our CORBA packages before the rt.=
jar.
> 
> Try this --
> java Xbootclasspath:<your DOM jar>;rt.jar
> 
> note=
: if you are in UNIX the separator should be a colon, not 
> a semicolon.
>=
 
> Let us know if that works.
> 
> -Jason
>

ocument

t

OM Document, and aRowSet is a String.

nge the PROJECTX libraries for the

orks!!!
